question:
The sentence below has been divided into three parts. Select the part of the sentence that has an error. If the sentence has no error, select the option 'No Error'.
If he had been entered a fatstock/ competition, I am sure his story would/ have been one of unrivalled success.

(IB ACIO 2023 T-1 : 17 Jan S2)
option_1: have been one of unrivalled success.
option_2: If he had been entered a fatstock
option_4: competition, I am sure his story would
solution:
Explanation:

‚ú¶ Error Type: Incorrect verb form in passive construction

‚ú¶ Part of Speech Affected: Verb phrase

‚ú¶ Rule Involved:

In passive voice, "enter" should follow the form "had been + past participle", but ‚Äúbeen entered‚Äù implies someone else entered him. However, the phrase "If he had been entered a fatstock competition" is missing the preposition "in" ‚Äî the correct phrase is "entered in a fatstock competition."

Also, more naturally, we would say:

"If he had entered a fatstock competition..." (active voice)
or
"If he had been entered in a fatstock competition..." (passive voice, with correct preposition)

‚úÖ Corrected Sentence:

If he had entered a fatstock competition, I am sure his story would have been one of unrivalled success.

OR (if passive intended):

If he had been entered in a fatstock competition, I am sure...

üß© Evaluation of Other Options:

  • "competition, I am sure his story would" ‚Äì ‚úî Grammatically correct.

  • "have been one of unrivalled success." ‚Äì ‚úî Grammatically correct future perfect form.

  • "If he had been entered a fatstock" ‚Äì ‚ùå Incorrect due to missing preposition and awkward passive usage.

‚úÖ Final Answer: If he had been entered a fatstock

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Neither of my sisters / are interested to come / on a vacation with me.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 17 Nov S-1)
option_4: on a vacation with me
solution:
Answer: (c) are interested to come

Explanation:

  • ‚ÄúNeither‚Äù is a singular subject, so the verb should also be singular.
    ‚úÖ It should be ‚Äúis‚Äù instead of ‚Äúare‚Äù.

  • Also, the correct construction is: ‚Äúinterested in coming‚Äù, not ‚Äúinterested to come‚Äù.
    So, the corrected phrase should be: ‚Äúis interested in coming‚Äù.

‚úÖ Correct sentence:
‚ÄúNeither of my sisters is interested in coming on a vacation with me.‚Äù

Hence, the error is in part (c).

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
The Government was / deaf on the protests and / continued with its plan.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 17 Nov S-3)
option_4: deaf on the protests and
solution:
Answer: (d) deaf on the protests and

Explanation:

  • The correct phrase is ‚Äúdeaf to the protests‚Äù, not ‚Äúdeaf on the protests‚Äù.

  • ‚ÄúDeaf to‚Äù means ignoring or not paying attention to something.

  • The rest of the sentence is correct.

Therefore, the error is in part (d).

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
It has / been raining / since / two hours.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 18 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Explanation:

  • The phrase "since two hours" is incorrect.

  • "Since" is used with a specific point in time (e.g., since 5 PM, since Monday, since 2020).

  • "For" is used with a duration or period of time (e.g., for two hours, for five days).

So, it should be:

It has been raining for two hours.

üõ†Ô∏è Part of Speech with Error:

Preposition ‚Äî incorrect use of ‚Äúsince‚Äù instead of ‚Äúfor‚Äù.

‚úÖ Correct Sentence:

It has been raining for two hours.

‚úîÔ∏è Final Answer: since ‚úÖ

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
The increase in irrigated areas / has resulted on achieving / record food grain production.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 18 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
option_2: The increase in irrigated areas
solution:
Step-by-step Analysis:

Part A: ‚ÄúThe increase in irrigated areas‚Äù

  • Subject phrase ‚Äì grammatically correct.

  • ‚úÖ No error here.
    (‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø)

Part B: ‚Äúhas resulted on achieving‚Äù

  • ‚ùå This is where the error lies.

‚ùó Error Type: Wrong preposition

üß† Rule:

The verb ‚Äúresult‚Äù is followed by the preposition ‚Äúin‚Äù, not ‚Äúon.‚Äù

‚úÖ Correct: "result in something" (‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ö‡•Ä‡§ú‡§º ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§π‡•ã‡§®‡§æ)

So:

‚ùå "has resulted on achieving"
‚úÖ "has resulted in achieving"

Part C: ‚Äúrecord food grain production‚Äù

  • Object of the gerund ‚Äúachieving‚Äù ‚Äì grammatically fine.

  • ‚úÖ No error here.
    (‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•â‡§∞‡•ç‡§° ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§® ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§®)

Part D: ‚ÄúNo error‚Äù

  • ‚ùå Not correct, since there is an error in Part B.

‚úÖ Correct Answer: has resulted on achieving

question:
The following sentence has been split into segments. One of them may contain an error. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
I had all / the comforts to life / in my childhood.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 18 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

Step-by-step Analysis:

Part A: "I had all"

  • Subject + verb phrase.

  • ‚ÄúHad‚Äù is correctly used in the past tense to express possession.

  • ‚úÖ No error here.
    (‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§¨ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§õ ‡§•‡§æ)

Part B: "the comforts to life"

  • ‚ùå This is incorrect.

‚ùó Error Type: Wrong preposition

üß† Rule:

The correct phrase is:

‚Äúcomforts of life‚Äù, not ‚Äúcomforts to life‚Äù.

  • ‚ÄúComforts of life‚Äù is a standard collocation in English, meaning the material or emotional benefits that make life easier or more enjoyable.
    (‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§® ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§è‡§Ç / ‡§Ü‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ)

Part C: "in my childhood"

  • Correct use of prepositional phrase to refer to time.

  • ‚úÖ No error.
    (‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•á ‡§¨‡§ö‡§™‡§® ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç)

Part D: "No error"

  • ‚ùå Incorrect choice because there is an error in Part B.

‚úÖ Correct Answer: the comforts to life

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.

We don't really / want a large house; / we are looking for some comfort / and some convenience on a moderate price.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 18 August Shift 1 (9 to 10 AM))
option_3: we are looking for some comfort
option_4: and some convenience on a moderate price
solution:
Correct Answer: and some convenience on a moderate price

Solution:
The error is in the phrase "on a moderate price".
The correct preposition is "at", not "on".
We say "at a moderate price" when referring to the cost of something.

Correct phrase: "at a moderate price"

Other Parts:

  • All other segments are grammatically correct and need no changes.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The visitors complained / at the poor accommodation / they were provided / during the tour.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 18 August Shift 3 (3 to 4 PM))
solution:
Answer: at the poor accommodation

Solution:

  • The verb complain must be followed by the preposition about (not at) when introducing the cause of dissatisfaction.

  • Therefore, ‚Äúat the poor accommodation‚Äù is incorrect; it should be ‚Äúabout the poor accommodation.‚Äù

Difficult word:

  • Accommodation ‚Äì a place to stay (‡§†‡§π‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§ó‡§π)

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
The present-century threats to our environment, / which include interfering species, ailments, pollution and / a boiling temperature, were putting wildlife populations at peril.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 18 July Shift-3)
option_1: which include interfering species, ailments, pollution, and
option_2: The present-century threats to our environment
option_3: a boiling temperature, were putting wildlife populations at peril
solution:
Answer: a boiling temperature, were putting wildlife populations at peril
Solution:

  • The sentence is in past tense and uses the phrase ‚Äúwere putting‚Äù, which is acceptable, but the issue lies in the phrase ‚Äúat peril‚Äù.

  • The correct idiom is ‚Äúin peril‚Äù, not ‚Äúat peril‚Äù.

  • In peril = in danger (‡§ñ‡§§‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç)

  • Also, "a boiling temperature" sounds awkward and unidiomatic in this context; "rising temperatures" or "global warming" would be better, but grammatically the main error is the preposition.

‚úÖ Therefore, the error is in the segment: ‚Äúa boiling temperature, were putting wildlife populations at peril‚Äù.
It should be: ‚Äú...were putting wildlife populations in peril.‚Äù

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
He was happy because / his friends voted / in favour to him.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-2)
solution:
Correct Answer: in favour to him
Explanation:
 The correct prepositional phrase is "in favour of him" (‡§â‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç), not "in favour to him".
 The phrase "in favour of" is used when someone supports or votes for a person or idea.

Correct sentence: He was happy because his friends voted in favour of him.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Saleem has a tendency to switch / off his mobile when things / are not favourable for him.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-2)
option_1: Saleem has a tendency to switch
option_2: are not favourable for him
option_4: off his mobile when things
solution:
Correct Answer:are not favourable for him
Explanation:
 The error lies in the phrase "are not favourable for him".
 The correct preposition after "favourable" is "to", not "for".
Correct phrase: favourable to him (‡§â‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤)

Correct sentence: Saleem has a tendency to switch off his mobile when things are not favourable to him.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Besides the banyan tree / is the path / that leads to the forest.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-3)
option_4: that leads to the forest
solution:
Answer:Besides the banyan tree

Explanation:

  • The phrase "Besides the banyan tree" is incorrect in context.


  • "Besides" means in addition to (‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§§), but here the sentence is referring to location, not addition.


The correct preposition should be:
 ‚úÖ "Beside the banyan tree", which means next to or by the side of (‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§ó‡§≤ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç).

Correct sentence:
"Beside the banyan tree is the path that leads to the forest."

‚úÖ Correct answer:Besides the banyan tree

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
She performed / the task / at the best / of her ability.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 19 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Explanation:

Correct Answer: at the best

üîç What‚Äôs the grammatical issue?

  • Error Type: Wrong idiomatic expression

  • Part of speech affected: Prepositional phrase (idiom)

üìò Correct Idiom:

The correct phrase is:
üëâ "to the best of her ability" ‚úÖ
Not: "at the best of her ability" ‚ùå

‚ùå ‚ÄúAt the best‚Äù ‚Äì is incorrect in this context.

The idiom ‚Äúto the best of [one‚Äôs] ability‚Äù means:
‚Üí as well as someone possibly can (‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞)

‚úÖ Other segments:

  • She performed ‚Äì ‚úÖ

  • Grammatically correct subject + verb

  • the task ‚Äì ‚úÖ

  • Proper noun phrase acting as object

  • of her ability ‚Äì ‚úÖ

  • Correct complement to the idiom "to the best"

üü¢ So, the segment with the grammatical error is: ‚Äúat the best‚Äù,

because it should be ‚Äúto the best‚Äù to form the correct idiom.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
It has been / raining intermittently / since two days.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 19 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Explanation:

Correct Answer: since two days

üîç What‚Äôs the grammatical issue?

  • Error Type: Wrong preposition usage (time expressions)

  • Part of speech affected: Preposition ‚Äúsince‚Äù

üìò Rule: "Since" vs. "For"

  • ‚ÄúSince‚Äù is used with a specific point in time
    üëâ Example: since Monday, since 5 PM, since 2020

  • ‚ÄúFor‚Äù is used with a duration of time
    üëâ Example: for two days, for an hour, for a long time

‚ùå ‚Äúsince two days‚Äù is incorrect ‚ùå

  • "Two days" is a duration, not a specific point in time
    ‚úî It should be: ‚Äúfor two days‚Äù

‚úÖ Evaluation of other parts:

  • It has been ‚Äì ‚úÖ
    ‚úî Correct present perfect continuous auxiliary

  • Raining intermittently ‚Äì ‚úÖ
    ‚úî Proper continuous verb form and adverb usage

  • No error ‚Äì ‚ùå There is an error in the ‚Äúsince‚Äù phrase

üü¢ So, the segment with the grammatical error is: ‚Äúsince two days‚Äù

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I was angry / on myself / for making / such a silly mistake.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 19 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

Correct Answer: on myself

üîç What‚Äôs the grammatical issue?

  • Error Type:Incorrect preposition usage

  • Part of speech affected:Preposition + Reflexive pronoun

üìò Grammar Rule Involved:

When expressing anger directed at oneself, the correct preposition is ‚Äúwith‚Äù, not ‚Äúon‚Äù.

  • ‚ùå ‚Äúangry on myself‚Äù is incorrect
    (common in Indian English, but grammatically wrong in standard usage)

  • ‚úÖ ‚Äúangry with myself‚Äù is correct
    (used to express self-directed frustration or blame)

üß† Think of similar phrases:

‚úÖ I‚Äôm angry with him.
‚úÖ She was angry with herself.
‚ùå I‚Äôm angry on anyone ‚Äî ‚ùå never correct.

‚ùå Evaluation of Other Segments (No Error):

  • I was angry ‚Äì ‚úÖ

  • Correct past simple structure (subject + verb)

  • for making ‚Äì ‚úÖ

  • Correct use of preposition "for" + gerund (making)

  • such a silly mistake ‚Äì ‚úÖ

  • Proper use of ‚Äúsuch‚Äù + adjective + noun

üü¢ So, the segment with the grammatical error is: on myself,

because it should be ‚Äúwith myself‚Äù when expressing anger directed at oneself.

question:
The following sentence has been split into segments. One of them may contain an error. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
He was formerly / a doctor of / the corporate hospital.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 19 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

‚úÖ Error Type:

Preposition misuse
Affected Part of Speech: Prepositional phrase
Grammar Rule:
We generally use "at" with institutions or organizations (like hospitals, schools, banks, companies) to refer to employment or association.

‚ùå Incorrect:

"a doctor of the corporate hospital"

This construction implies ownership (as if the doctor belongs to the hospital), which is not idiomatic in English.

‚úÖ Correct:

"a doctor at the corporate hospital"
(Meaning: He worked there as a doctor.)

üîÅ Corrected Sentence:

He was formerly a doctor at the corporate hospital.

Other options:

  • He was formerly ‚úÖ
    ‚úîÔ∏è Correct adverb of time used appropriately.
    (formerly = ‡§™‡§π‡§≤‡•á)

  • the corporate hospital ‚úÖ
    ‚úîÔ∏è Correct noun phrase.
    (corporate hospital = ‡§ï‡•â‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§ü ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡§æ‡§≤)

  • No error ‚ùå
    There is an error (in preposition), so this is incorrect.

‚úÖ Final Answer: a doctor of

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
They will go to bed / early since they / have to get up / at five on the morning.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 2 Dec Shift-3)
option_2: at five on the morning
option_3: They will go to bed
solution:
Correct Answer: at five on the morning

Explanation:

  • The correct prepositional phrase is ‚Äúat five in the morning,‚Äù not ‚Äúon the morning.‚Äù

  • We use ‚Äúin‚Äù with parts of the day (in the morning/afternoon/evening), and ‚Äúon‚Äù with days or dates (on Monday, on July 10).

Thus, the erroneous segment is ‚Äúat five on the morning.‚Äù

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
She, often, accuses him for a lack of morality.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 2 Dec Shift-4)
solution:
Correct Answer: accuses him for

Explanation:

  • The verb accuse correctly pairs with ‚Äúof‚Äù, not ‚Äúfor‚Äù‚Äîwe accuse someone of something.

  • The sentence should read:
    ‚ÄúShe often accuses him of a lack of morality.‚Äù

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains a grammatical error.
There was no denying the fact / that King Lear confided to / his daughter Cordelia / more than anybody else.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 2 Dec Shift-4)
option_1: There was no denying the fact
option_3: that King Lear confided to
solution:
Correct Answer: that King Lear confided to

Explanation:
The verb confide correctly pairs with the preposition in, not to. We confide in someone when we trust them with private information (‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ù‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ).

  • Incorrect: confided to

  • Correct: confided in

All other parts are grammatically correct.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
At the last meeting / which took place in November, / half the members submitted / their resignations on protest.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 20 August Shift 2 (12 to 1 PM))
option_3: which took place in November
solution:
Answer: their resignations on protest

Solution:

  • The noun ‚Äúresignations‚Äù must be followed by the preposition ‚Äúin‚Äù when indicating the reason or manner of protest.

  • The correct phrase is ‚Äúsubmitted their resignations in protest‚Äù, not ‚Äúon protest.‚Äù

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
I never miss / a cricket match / as I am fond of cricket / from childhood.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 20 August Shift 3 (3 to 4 PM))
option_1: as I am fond of cricket
solution:
Answer: from childhood

Solution:

  • The phrase ‚Äúfrom childhood‚Äù is incorrect here because when indicating the starting point of a state that continues to the present, English uses ‚Äúsince‚Äù rather than ‚Äúfrom.‚Äù

  • The corrected segment should read ‚Äúsince childhood.‚Äù

Difficult word:

  • fond of: liking something a lot; ‡§™‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain a grammatical error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
They ordered the whole area / to be disinfected / on the earliest.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 21 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
option_1: They ordered the whole area
solution:
üîç Explanation of the Error:

The phrase "on the earliest" is grammatically incorrect.
The correct phrase should be:

"at the earliest" ‚úÖ

üîÑ Corrected Sentence:

They ordered the whole area to be disinfected at the earliest.

üìö Rule Involved:

  • The correct prepositional phrase used to express urgency or immediacy is:

  • "at the earliest" (as in: Please reply at the earliest.)

  • ‚ùå "On the earliest" is not used in standard English.

‚úÖ Evaluation of Other Options:

  • They ordered the whole area ‚Äì ‚úÖ No error (subject + verb + object)

  • to be disinfected ‚Äì ‚úÖ No error (passive infinitive form; correctly used)

  • on the earliest ‚Äì ‚ùå Incorrect usage of preposition

üìù Final Answer: on the earliest

question:
The following sentence has been split into segments. One of them may contain an error. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Among you and me / she is quite rude / to the boy.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 21 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

Step-by-step Analysis:

‚úÖ ‚Äúshe is quite rude‚Äù

‚Äì Grammatically correct.
‚Äì "Is quite rude" is a valid verb phrase in present tense. No error here.

‚úÖ ‚Äúto the boy‚Äù

‚Äì Prepositional phrase used properly. No grammatical issue.

‚ùå ‚ÄúAmong you and me‚Äù

This is the problematic part.

üîé Rule Involved:
When comparing two people, the correct preposition is "between", not "among".

  • Among is used for more than two.

  • Between is used for two entities.

Also, ‚ÄúBetween you and me‚Äù is the correct pronoun usage (objective case), which is already correct in terms of pronoun.

‚úÖ Correct Usage:

‚ÄúBetween you and me‚Äù ‚Äî not ‚ÄúAmong you and me‚Äù

üìå Final Answer: Among you and me ‚úÖ

Error type: Incorrect preposition
Part of speech affected: Preposition
Correct version:‚ÄúBetween you and me‚Äù

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Vivek should be excited / on the promotion / he‚Äôs got.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 21 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

Grammar Rule Involved:

‚ùó The preposition "on" is incorrect in this context.

‚úÖ The correct preposition after ‚Äúexcited‚Äù when referring to a reason/cause (like a promotion) is usually ‚Äúabout‚Äù or ‚Äúby‚Äù, not ‚Äúon‚Äù.

üîÅ Corrected Sentence:

Vivek should be excited about the promotion he‚Äôs got.

üß† Part of Speech Affected:

  • Preposition: "on" should be "about"

  • Phrase error type: Incorrect preposition usage

‚ùå Option-wise Evaluation:

  • A. Vivek should be excited ‚Äî ‚úÖ Correct

  • B. on the promotion ‚Äî ‚ùå Incorrect; should be "about the promotion"

  • C. he‚Äôs got ‚Äî ‚úÖ Correct (present perfect used for recent experience/result)

  • D. No error ‚Äî ‚ùå Incorrect

‚úÖ Final Answer: B. on the promotion

(Correct form: "about the promotion" ‚Äî ‡§™‡§¶‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã‡§®‡§æ ‡§ö‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§è)

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Shall / we go / for walking / in the park?

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 21 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

Grammar Rule Involved:

The verb ‚Äúgo‚Äù is usually followed by the gerund form of an activity without using ‚Äúfor.‚Äù

‚úÖ Correct structure:

  • go walking, go swimming, go running, etc.
    ‚ùå Not: go for walking

üß† Part of Speech Affected:

  • Preposition usage: ‚Äúfor walking‚Äù is incorrect.

  • Correct form:"go walking"
    (‚ÄúWalking‚Äù is a gerund used directly after ‚Äúgo.‚Äù)

üîÅ Correct Sentence:

Shall we go walking in the park?

‚ùå Option-wise Evaluation:

  • A. Shall ‚Äì ‚úÖ Correct (Modal verb for suggestion)

  • B. we go ‚Äì ‚úÖ Correct (Simple structure with modal)

  • C. for walking ‚Äì ‚ùå Incorrect (Should be just ‚Äúwalking‚Äù)

  • D. in the park ‚Äì ‚úÖ Correct (Proper prepositional phrase)

‚úÖ Final Answer: C. for walking

(Correct usage: "go walking" ‚Äì ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§≤‡§®‡•á ‡§ö‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ?)

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
He conceded / a very crucial / point at / his opponent.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 21 Apr S3 (4 to 5 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

üìå Correct preposition after "concede" (something) is ‚Äúto‚Äù, not ‚Äúat.‚Äù

  • ‚úÖ Concede something to someone
    ‚Üí ‚ÄúHe conceded a point to his opponent.‚Äù (‡§â‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§è‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ‡§¨‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Å ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§)

‚ùå Error is in:

"point at" ‚Üí it should be "point to"

‚úÖ Correct Answer: point at

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
Several prominent film stars / have appeared on television / on behalf of awareness / about hand hygiene.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 23 August Shift 1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Answer: on behalf of awareness

Correction:to raise awareness / for spreading awareness

Solution:
The phrase "on behalf of awareness" is incorrect and unidiomatic.
‚Ä¢ "On behalf of" means representing someone, not something abstract like "awareness".
‚Ä¢ The correct expression should be "to raise awareness" or "for spreading awareness".

Correct sentence:
Several prominent film stars have appeared on television to raise awareness about hand hygiene.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them contains an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options.
Mithila art tradition is passed on / from one generation through a next / by children watching and helping / their mothers and grandmothers.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 24 August Shift 3 (3 to 4 PM))
option_1: Mithila art tradition is passed on
option_3: by children watching and helping
option_4: from one generation through a next
solution:
Answer: from one generation through a next

Explanation:

The phrase "from one generation through a next" is grammatically incorrect.
The correct expression is: "from one generation to the next."

  • "From...to..." is the standard prepositional pair used to indicate movement or transition.

  • "A next" is incorrect because ‚Äúnext‚Äù is a determiner, and doesn‚Äôt require an article like ‚Äúa‚Äù here.

Correct sentence:
Mithila art tradition is passed on from one generation to the next by children watching and helping their mothers and grandmothers.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I play / cricket in / my childhood / with my sister.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 24 July Shift-3)
solution:
Answer:(3) my childhood

Solution:
The phrase ‚Äúmy childhood‚Äù is incorrect here because the sentence is in present tense, but "childhood" refers to the past. Also, the phrase should use ‚Äúin my childhood‚Äù with a past tense verb like "played."

Correct sentence:
‚ÄúI played cricket in my childhood with my sister.‚Äù

Word Meanings:

  • Childhood ‚Äì ‡§¨‡§ö‡§™‡§®

  • Play ‚Äì ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≤‡§®‡§æ

  • Cricket ‚Äì ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§ü

  • Sister ‚Äì ‡§¨‡§π‡§®

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I caught / a white cat / rustling / beneath my room.

(SSC SP Ph-11 : 27 June Shift-4 )
solution:
The segment containing the grammatical error is: "beneath my room."

The correct preposition to use in this context is "under,"

the phrase "beneath my room" is a bit unusual in English usage. While "beneath" can mean "underneath," it's more common to use "under" when referring to the location of something in relation to another object.

So, the grammatical error lies in the choice of the preposition "beneath" instead of "under" to convey the relationship between the action of catching the cat and its location. Therefore, the corrected segment should be: "under my room."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Kids learn / a lot by / their / school activities and homework.

(SSC SP Ph-11 : 28 June Shift-3 )
solution:
The correct answer is ‚Äúa lot by‚Äù.

The correct use of preposition should be from instead of by.

So, the correct sentence would be: kids learn a lot from their school activities and homework.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
There is a whole world / out there that / is invisible from / the naked eye.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 3 Dec Shift-1)
option_2: There is a whole world
solution:
Answer: is invisible from

Explanation:
The correct preposition is to, not from. It should read ‚Äúis invisible to the naked eye.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúInvisible to‚Äù is the standard collocation for something not detectable by sight.

question:
Select the option that contains a grammatical error in the underlined portion.
There are three cupholders placed on the cupboards of the secretariat table.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 3 Dec Shift-2)
option_1: There are three cupholders placed on the cupboards of the secretariat table.
option_2: There are three cupholders placed on the cupboards of the secretariat table.
option_3: There are three cupholders placed on the cupboards of the secretariat table.
option_4: There are three cupholders placed on the cupboards of the secretariat table.
solution:
Answer: placed on the cupboards

Explanation:
The error is in the phrase placed on the cupboards, because you‚Äôd normally place a cupholder in or on a single cupboard rather than ‚Äúon the cupboards.‚Äù It should read:

There are three cupholders in the cupboard of the secretariat table.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains a grammatical error. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Amla juice / is rich with / Vitamin C. / no error

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 3 Dec Shift-4)
solution:
Answer: is rich with

Explanation:
The correct collocation is ‚Äúrich in‚Äù, not ‚Äúrich with.‚Äù The sentence should read:

Amla juice is rich in Vitamin C.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The postman / delivers the letters / through hand, / door to door.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-1 (9 to 11 AM))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: through hand
"through hand": This segment contains the grammatical error. The phrase "through hand" is incorrect. The correct phrase should be "by hand," which means using one's hands or manually. So, this segment needs to be corrected to "by hand."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I have never / come to / such a kind person / like my friend.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 4 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: "like my friend"
The correct form should be: "such a kind person as my friend"
Explanation:

The error lies in the use of the preposition "like" instead of "as." When making comparisons, "as" is used to introduce the clause indicating the thing being compared to, while "like" is used before a noun or pronoun to indicate similarity. In this context, "as" is appropriate for the comparison.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
They hÃ≤aÃ≤dÃ≤ Ã≤tÃ≤wÃ≤oÃ≤ bÃ≤eÃ≤dÃ≤rÃ≤oÃ≤oÃ≤mÃ≤sÃ≤ Ã≤aÃ≤mÃ≤oÃ≤nÃ≤gÃ≤ tÃ≤hÃ≤eÃ≤mÃ≤,Ã≤ Ã≤oÃ≤nÃ≤eÃ≤ Ã≤fÃ≤oÃ≤rÃ≤ the gÃ≤iÃ≤rÃ≤lÃ≤sÃ≤ Ã≤aÃ≤nÃ≤dÃ≤ Ã≤oÃ≤nÃ≤eÃ≤ for the boys.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 4_Sept_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: 4
Solution: The error is in the segment "bedrooms among".

The word "among" is incorrect here because it implies distribution within a group, which is not the intended meaning. The correct preposition should be "between", which is used when referring to a choice or distribution involving two distinct groups or entities.

Correct phrase:
"had two bedrooms between them"

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Why don‚Äôt / you throw this / paper on the dust bin?

(SSC MTS 2023 : 4_Sept_Shift-3)
option_3: paper on the dust bin
solution:
Answer: 3
Solution: The error is in the segment "paper on the dust bin."

The correct preposition is "in" when referring to putting something inside a container like a dustbin.

Correct sentence:
"Why don‚Äôt you throw this paper in the dustbin?"

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains a grammatical error.
The jury was not happy with the performance / and was quite harsh. / The singer took / their criticism in heart.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 5 Dec Shift-1)
option_1: The jury was not happy with the performance
solution:
Answer: their criticism in heart.

Explanation:
The idiomatic phrase is ‚Äútake something to heart,‚Äù not ‚Äúin heart.‚Äù Therefore, the error lies in using the wrong preposition. The correct segment should read:

The singer took their criticism to heart.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
He will make mistakes, but he will learn / by making mistakes. So, dear parents, / once you put the money in your / children‚Äôs little pockets, forget all on it.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 5 Dec Shift-2)
option_1: once you put the money in your
option_2: by making mistakes. So, dear parents,
option_3: children‚Äôs little pockets, forget all on it
option_4: He will make mistakes, but he will learn
solution:
Answer: children‚Äôs little pockets, forget all on it

Explanation:
The phrase should be ‚Äúforget all about it‚Äù, not ‚Äúon it.‚Äù The correct segment is:

‚Ä¶once you put the money in your children‚Äôs little pockets, forget all about it.

‚ÄúAll about it‚Äù is the standard expression meaning don‚Äôt worry or think further regarding that (‡§â‡§∏ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§ó‡•á ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§æ).

question:
Select the option that contains a grammatical error in the underlined portion.
There are no tables at the classroom.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 5 Dec Shift-4)
option_1: There are nÃ≤oÃ≤ Ã≤tÃ≤aÃ≤bÃ≤lÃ≤eÃ≤sÃ≤ at the classroom.
option_2: There are no tables at the cÃ≤lÃ≤aÃ≤sÃ≤sÃ≤rÃ≤oÃ≤oÃ≤mÃ≤.
option_3: TÃ≤hÃ≤eÃ≤rÃ≤eÃ≤ Ã≤aÃ≤rÃ≤eÃ≤ no tables at the classroom.
option_4: There are no tables aÃ≤tÃ≤ Ã≤tÃ≤hÃ≤eÃ≤ classroom.
solution:
Answer: There are no tables at the classroom.

Explanation:

  • The correct preposition for a place like ‚Äúclassroom‚Äù is in, not at.

  • The correct phrase should be ‚ÄúThere are no tables in the classroom.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúAt‚Äù is used for a general location, but ‚Äúin‚Äù is used for being inside an enclosed space like a classroom.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The students / are expected / to come / in the right time.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 5 Oct Shift-1 (9 to 11 AM))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: (b) in the right time

The correct preposition to use in this context is "on" instead of "in."

Therefore, the corrected sentence would be: "The students are expected to come on the right time."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
The prisoner was / accused for stealing / from his landlord.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 6 Dec Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: accused for stealing

Explanation:

  • The correct preposition with accused is of, not for.

  • It should be: ‚ÄúThe prisoner was accused of stealing from his landlord.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúAccused for‚Äù is a common error in English usage.

  • The other parts are correct.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains a grammatical error. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
 I am having trouble / deciding in / a gift for them. / no error

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 6 Dec Shift-4)
solution:
Answer: deciding in

Explanation:

  • The correct preposition after deciding is on, not in.

  • It should read: ‚ÄúI am having trouble deciding on a gift for them.‚Äù

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
She is very good / in playing / the guitar / and singing songs.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 6_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: (3) in playing
Solution:
‚Ä¢ The phrase "very good in playing" is grammatically incorrect.
‚Ä¢ The correct preposition to use with "good" when referring to a skill or activity is "at", not "in"
‚Ä¢ So, it should be: "She is very good at playing the guitar and singing songs."

Grammar Rule:
‚Ä¢ Use "good at + noun/gerund" to talk about skills or abilities
‚Äì e.g., He is good at drawing.
‚Äì They are good at maths.

Incorrect: good in playing ‚ùå
Correct: good at playing ‚úÖ

Therefore, the error lies in segment (3) in playing, and it should be corrected to "at playing" ‚úÖ

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
She has / a habit of / spending against / her means.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 8 Dec Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: spending against

Explanation:

  • The idiomatic expression is ‚Äúspending beyond one‚Äôs means‚Äù, not ‚Äúagainst.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúBeyond‚Äù conveys exceeding financial limits, whereas ‚Äúagainst‚Äù is incorrect here.

  • All other segments are grammatically and idiomatically sound.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
She has / not written / a single novel / by three years.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 8 Dec Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: by three years

Explanation:
The preposition by is used for deadlines or points in time, not durations. To express that she hasn‚Äôt written anything over a period, use for three years.

  • Use for with time spans (for three years)

  • Reserve by for deadlines (by Monday, by 2025)

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
This scripture / has been /translated in / seventy languages.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 8_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: (3) translated in
Solution:
‚Ä¢ The error is in the phrase "translated in"
‚Ä¢ The correct preposition with "translated" is "into" when referring to languages
‚Ä¢ So, it should be "translated into seventy languages" instead of "translated in seventy languages"
‚Ä¢ The phrase "translated in" is incorrect usage here
‚Ä¢ Correct sentence: "This scripture has been translated into seventy languages."
‚Ä¢ Therefore, segment (3) contains the grammatical error.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
I tÃ≤oÃ≤lÃ≤dÃ≤ Rahu oÃ≤nÃ≤ wait fÃ≤oÃ≤rÃ≤ two hours aÃ≤tÃ≤ the bus stop.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 9 Dec Shift-4)
solution:
Answer: on

Explanation:
The error lies in using on before ‚Äúwait.‚Äù With told, we require the to-infinitive form (told someone to do something), not a preposition.

  • The sentence should be:
    ‚ÄúI told Rahu to wait for two hours at the bus stop.‚Äù

  • The phrases ‚Äòfor two hours‚Äô and ‚Äòat the bus stop‚Äô are correct.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Huda lived in / the southern part / off Germany.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 9 Dec Shift-4)
solution:
Answer: off Germany

Explanation:
The error is the preposition off. In English, we say ‚Äúpart of‚Äù to indicate belonging, not ‚Äúpart off.‚Äù The correct phrase is:

Huda lived in the southern part of Germany.

  • Use of with ‚Äúpart‚Äù to show possession or inclusion.

  • ‚ÄúOff‚Äù implies separation or removal, which is incorrect here.
